abstractText: A radio labeling of a graph G is a function f : V (G) → {0, 1, 2, . . .} such that |f(u) − f(v)| ≥ diam(G) + 1− d(u, v) for every pair of distinct vertices u, v of G. The radio number of G, denoted by rn(G), is the smallest number k such that G has radio labeling f with max{f(v) : v ∈ V (G)} = k. In this paper, we give a lower bound for the radio number for the Cartesian product of the generalized Petersen graph and tree. We present two necessary and sufficient conditions, and three other sufficient conditions to achieve the lower bound. Using these results, we determine the radio number for the Cartesian product of the Peterson graph and stars.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
The channel assignment problem, introduced by Hale in [11], deals with the task of assigning
channels to the radio transmitters so that the interference constraints between two transmitters
is satisfied and the span of channels used is kept to a minimum. The interference between
two transmitters is primarily dependent on the proximity of transmitters. The closer the two
transmitters are, higher the interference is and vice-versa. Initially, only two levels of interference
were considered, namely minor and major, and accordingly two transmitters are classified as
close and very close transmitters.
The problem of assignment of channels to transmitters is studied using a graph model in
which transmitters are represented by vertices of a graph such that two vertices are adjacent if
major interference occurs and at distance two if minor interference occurs between those two
corresponding transmitters. It is assumed that there is no interference if the vertices are distance
two apart in the graph model. Roberts[16] suggested that a pair of transmitters having minor
interference must receive different channels and a pair of transmitters having major interference
must receive channels that are at least two apart. Motivated through this, Griggs and Yeh[10]
introduced L(2, 1)-labeling which is also known as distance two labeling as follows: An L(2, 1)- labeling (or distance two labeling) of a graph G = (V (G), E(G)) is a function f : V (G) → {0, 1, 2, ...} such that for each pair of distinct vertices u and v satisfies the following conditions:
|f(u)− f(v)| ≥ {

where d(u, v) is the distance between u and v in G. The span of f is defined as span(f) = max{|f(u)−f(v)| : u, v ∈ V (G)} and the λ-number (or the λ2,1-number) of G, denoted by λ(G) (or λ2,1(G)), is the minimum span of an L(2, 1)-labeling of G. An L(2, 1)-labeling f of G is called optimal if span(f) = λ(G). The readers can refer the survey article [6] and [20] for recent
results on L(2, 1)-labeling of graph G.
It is observed that the interference among transmitters might go beyond two levels. A radio
labeling extends the level of interference considered in L(2, 1)-labeling from two to the largest
possible - the diameter of G. Motivated through this, Chartrand et al.[7, 8] introduced the
concept of radio labeling of a graph as follows:
Definition 1.1. A radio labeling of a graph G is a mapping f : V (G)→ {0, 1, 2, . . .} such that for every pair of distinct vertices u, v of G,
|f(u)− f(v)| ≥ diam(G) + 1− d(u, v).
The integer f(u) is called the label of u under f , and the span of f is defined as
span(f) = max{|f(u)− f(v)| : u, v ∈ V (G)}.
The radio number of G is defined as
rn(G) = min f span(f)
with minimum taken over all radio labelings f of G. A radio labeling f of G is called optimal if
span(f) = rn(G). If diam(G) = 2 then radio labeling of G is same as L(2, 1)-labeling of G.
A radio labeling always assign label 0 to some vertex then the maximum label used is a
span(f). It is an interesting and challenging task to find radio number for the graph. The
radio labeling problem is well studied for trees by several authors; refer [3, 12, 13, 14, 15]. The
radio labeling is studied only for handful graph families other than trees. The radio number for all graphs of order n and diameter n − 2 is determined by Benson et al. in [4]. Cada et al. studied the radio number of distance graph in [5]. Saha and Panigrahi studied the radio
number for toroidal grids and square of graphs in [17] and [18], respectively. Bantva and Liu
gave a lower bound for the radio number of block graphs and presented three necessary and
sufficient condition to achieve the lower bound in [1]. The same authors also discussed the radio
number of line graph of trees which are block graphs. Das et al. gave a technique to find a
lower bound for the radio number of graphs in [9]. In [21], Zhou discussed the problem of radio
channel assignment for the network modelled by Cayley graphs. Bantva and Liu discussed the
radio number of Cartesian product of two trees in [2].
The paper is structured as follows. In Section 2, we define necessary terms and notations
required for the present work. In Section 3, we give a lower bound for the radio number of the
Cartesian product of the generalized Peterson graph and a tree. We present two necessary and
sufficient conditions and, three other sufficient conditions for a lower bound to be tight. Finally,
using these results, we determine the radio number for the Cartesian product of the Peterson
graph and stars.

sections.heading: 2 Preliminaries
sections.text:
In this section, we define necessary terms and notations which will be used in the present work.
We follow [19] for standard graph theoretic definitions and notations. The distance between two
vertices u and v in a graph G, denoted by d(u, v), is the length of the shortest path joining u and v in a graph G. The diameter of a graph G is diam(G) = max{d(u, v) : u, v ∈ G}. The weight of a graph G from a vertex u ∈ V (G) is defined as wG(u) = ∑ v∈V (G) d(u, v). A vertex c ∈ V (G) is said to be weight center of G if wG(c) = min{wG(u) : u ∈ V (G)}. The weight of graph G, denoted by w(G), is defined as w(G) = wG(c), where c is the weight center of the graph G. Denote the set of all weight centers of graph G by W (G). A tree T is a simple connected
acyclic graph. The following is known about weight center(s) of a tree T .
Lemma 2.1. [15] If w is a weight center of a tree T . Then each component of T − w contains at most |V (T )|/2 vertices.
Lemma 2.2. [15] Every tree T has one or two weight centers, and T has two weight centers, say, W (T ) = {w,w′} if and only if ww′ is an edge of T and T −ww′ consists of two equal sized components.
For a tree T rooted at r, if x is on the r − y path then x is called ancestor of y and y is called descendant of x. Note that the root of the tree T is an ancestor of every vertex and every
vertex is its own ancestor and descendant.
If W (T ) = {w} then we view a tree T rooted at w and if W (T ) = {w,w′} then we view a tree T rooted at both w and w′. Let u be any vertex adjacent to the weight center of T , then
the subtree induced by u with all its descendants is called a branch of a tree T . Two branches
are called different if they induced by different vertices adjacent to the same weight center and
opposite if they induced by different vertices adjacent to different weight centers. Two vertices
u and v are said to be in different branches if either u and v are in different branches or one
of them is a weight center of T and other is in the branch of T induced by the vertex adjacent to it. If W (T ) = {w,w′} then u and v are said to be in opposite branches if they belong to different components of T − ww′. Define a level function LT : V (T )→ {0, 1, 2, . . .} by
LT (x) := min{d(x,w) : w ∈W (T )}.
The value of LT (x) is called level of the vertex x in T . The total level of T , denoted by L(T ), is defined as
L(T ) := ∑
x∈V (T )
LT (x).
For any two vertices x, y ∈ V (T ), define
φT (x, y) = max{LT (z) : z is a common ancestor of x and y},
δT (x, y) = { 1, if |W (T )| = 2 and, x and y are in opposite branches, 0, otherwise.
Define

0, if |W (T )| = 2.
Observation 2.3. Let T be a tree and x, y ∈ V (T ), then
(1) 0 ≤ φT (x, y) < max{LT (v) : v ∈ V (T )},
(2) φT (x, y) = 0 if and only if x and y are in opposite or different branches,
(3) dT (x, y) = LT (x) + LT (y) + δT (x, y)− 2φT (x, y).
Definition 2.4. For integers m ≥ 3 and k ≥ 1, the generalized Petersen graph Pm,k is the graph with vertex set V (Pm,k) = {ui, vi : i ∈ Zm} and edge set E(Pm,k) = {uiui+1, uivi, vivi+k : i ∈ Zm}.
Definition 2.5. Let G and H be any two simple connected graphs. The Cartesian product of G and H is denoted by G2H with vertex set V (G) × V (H), where two vertices (g, h) and (g′, h′) are adjacent in G2H if and only if g and g′ are adjacent in G and h = h′ in H; or h and h′ are adjacent in H and g = g′ in G.
Observation 2.6. Let G be any graph of order m with diameter d1 and H be any graph of order n with diameter d2, then
(1) |V (G2H)| = mn,
(2) diam(G2H) = d1 + d2,
(3) For any two vertices (g1, h1) and (g2, h2) in G2H,
dG2H((g1, h1), (g2, h2)) = dG(g1, g2) + dH(h1, h2).

sections.heading: 3 Main results
sections.text:
In this section, we continue to use terms and notations defined in previous section. Note that a
radio labeling f of graph G induced an ordering O(V (G)) := z0, z1, . . . , z|V (G)|−1 of V (G) such that
0 = f(z0) < f(z1) < . . . < f(zp−1) = span(f).
Theorem 3.1. Let Pm,k be a generalized Petersen graph of order 2m and T be a tree of order n. Denote diam(Pm,k2T ) = dG, diam(Pm,k) = dp, diam(T ) = dt and ε(T ) = ε. Then
rn(Pm,k2T ) ≥ (2mn− 1)(dt + ε)− 4mL(T ). (1)
Moreover, the equality holds in (1) if and only if there exist an ordering O(V (Pm,k2T )) := z0, z1, . . . , z2mn−1 of V (Pm,k2T ), where zt = (xit , yjt) such that the following all holds for all 0 ≤ t ≤ 2mn− 2:
(a) dPm,k(xit , xit+1) = dp,
(b) LT (yj0) + LT (yj2mn−1) = 0,
(c) yjt and yjt+1 are in different branches when |W (T )| = 1 and in opposite branches when |W (T )| = 2,
(d) the mapping f defined on O(V (Pm,k2T )) by f(z0) = 0 and f(zt+1) = f(zt) + dt + ε − LT (yjt)− LT (yjt+1) is a radio labeling of Pm,k2T .
Proof. Denote G = Pm,k2T . It is suffices to prove that the span of any radio labeling f of G is no less than the right-hand side of (1). Let f be any radio labeling of Pm,k2T with 0 = f(z0) < f(z1) < . . . < f(z2mn−1) = span(f). Since f is a radio labeling, we have f(zi+1)− f(zi) ≥ dG + 1 − dG(zi, zi+1) = dp + dt + 1 − dG(zi, zi+1) for 0 ≤ i ≤ 2mn − 2. Summing up these 2mn− 1 inequalities, we obtain
span(f) = f(z2mn−1) ≥ (2mn− 1)(dp + dt + 1)− 2mn−2∑ i=0 dG(zi, zi+1) (2)
Denote zt = (xit , yjt) for 0 ≤ t ≤ 2mn−1, where xit ∈ V (Pm,k) and yjt ∈ V (T ). By Observations 2.3 and 2.6, we have
2mn−2∑ t=0 dG(zt, zt+1) = 2mn−2∑ t=0 [dPm,k(xit , xit+1) + dT (yjt , yjt+1)]
≤ 2mn−2∑ t=0 [dp + LT (yjt) + LT (yjt+1) + δT (yjt , yjt+1)− 2φT (yjt , yjt+1)] = (2mn− 1)dp + 2 2mn−1∑ t=0 LT (yjt)− LT (yj0)− LT (yj2mn−1)
+ 2mn−2∑ t=0 [δT (yjt , yjt+1)− 2φT (yjt , yjt+1)]
= (2mn− 1)dp + 4mL(T )− LT (yj0)− LT (yj2mn−1)
+ 2mn−2∑ t=0 [δT (yjt , yjt+1)− 2φT (yjt , yjt+1)]. (3)
We consider the following two cases. Case-1: |W (T )| = 1. In this case, δT (yjt , yjt+1) = 0, φT (yjt , yjt+1) ≥ 0 for all 0 ≤ t ≤ 2mn − 2 and LT (yj0) +
LT (yj2mn−1) ≥ 0. Substituting these all in (3), we get
2mn−2∑ t=0 dG(zt, zt+1) ≤ (2mn− 1)dp + 4mL(T ). (4)
Substituting (4) in (2), we obtain
span(f) = f(z2mn−1) ≥ (2mn− 1)(dt + 1)− 4mL(T ).
Case-2: |W (T )| = 2. In this case, 0 ≤ δT (yjt , yjt+1) ≤ 1, φT (yjt , yjt+1) ≥ 0 for all 0 ≤ t ≤ 2mn− 2 and LT (yj0) +
LT (yj2mn−1) ≥ 0. Substituting these all in (3), we get
2mn−2∑ t=0 dG(zt, zt+1) ≤ (2mn− 1)dp + 4mL(T ) + (2mn− 1). (5)
Substituting (5) in (3), we obtain
span(f) = f(z2mn−1) ≥ (2mn− 1)dt − 4mL(T ).
It is easy to see from above Cases 1 and 2 that the equality hold in (1) if and only if the
conditions in moreover part hold which completes the proof.
Theorem 3.2. Let Pm,k be a generalized Petersen graph of order 2m and T be a tree of order n. Denote Pm,k2T = G, diam(Pm,k2T ) = dG, diam(Pm,k) = dp, diam(T ) = dt and ε(T ) = ε. Then
rn(Pm,k2T ) = (2mn− 1)(dt + ε)− 4mL(T ) (6)
if and only if there exist an ordering O(V (Pm,k2T )) := z0, z1, . . . , z2mn−1 of V (Pm,k2T ), where zt = (xit , yjt) such that the following all holds for all 0 ≤ t ≤ 2mn− 2:
(a) dPm,k(xit , xit+1) = dp,
(b) LT (yj0) + LT (yj2mn−1) = 0,
(c) For any za = (xia , yja) and zb = (xib , yjb), 0 ≤ a < b ≤ 2mn− 1; the distance dPm,k(xia , xib) and dT (yja , yjb) satisfies
dT (yja , yjb) + dPm,k(xia , xib) ≥ b−1∑ t=a (LT (yjt) + LT (yjt+1)− dt − ε) + dt + dp + 1. (7)
Proof. Necessity: Suppose (6) holds. By Theorem 3.1, there exist a radio labeling f of Pm,k2T with 0 = f(z0) < f(z1) < . . . < f(z2mn−1) = rn(Pm,k2T ), where zt = (xit , yjt), xit ∈ V (Pm,k) and yjt ∈ V (T ) such that the conditions (a)-(d) in Theorem 3.1 hold. Hence, the conditions (a) and (b) are satisfied. For any two vertices za and zb (0 ≤ a < b ≤ 2mn − 1), by the condition (d) of Theorem 3.1, we have
f(zb)− f(za) = b−1∑ t=a (dt + ε− LT (yjt)− LT (yjt+1)).
Since f is a radio labeling, f(zb) − f(za) ≥ dG + 1 − dG(za, zb) = dp + dt + 1 − dT (yja , yjb) − dPm,k(xia , xib). Substituting this in above equation, we obtain
b−1∑ t=a (dt + ε− LT (yjt)− LT (yjt+1)) = f(zb)− f(za) ≥ dp + dt + 1− dT (yja , yjb)− dPm,k(xia , xib).
Hence, the condition (c) is satisfied.
Sufficiency: Let an ordering O(V (Pm,k2T )) := z0, z1, . . . , z2mn−1 of V (Pm,k2T ) satisfying the conditions (a)-(c) of hypothesis. We prove that (6) holds and for this purpose, it is enough to
show that the conditions (c) and (d) in Theorem 3.1 hold. Take a = t and b = t+1 in (7), we have dT (yjt , yjt+1) ≥ LT (yjt)+LT (yjt+1)+1−ε which implies that yjt and yjt+1 are in different branches when |W (T )| = 1 and opposite branches when |W (T )| = 2. Hence, the condition (c) in Theorem 3.1 is satisfied. Let f is defined by f(z0) = 0 and f(zt+1) = f(zt) + dt + ε−LT (yjt)−LT (yjt+1) for 0 ≤ t ≤ 2mn− 2. We prove that f is a radio labeling. Let za and zb (0 ≤ a < b ≤ 2mn− 1) be two arbitrary vertices. Then
f(zb)− f(za) = b−1∑ t=a (dt + ε− LT (yjt)− LT (yjt+1))
≥ dp + dt + 1− dPm,k(xia , xib)− dT (yja , yjb) = dG + 1− dG(za, zb).
Hence f is a radio labeling. Thus the condition (d) of Theorem 3.1 is satisfied. The proof is
complete.
In the next result, we give three sufficient conditions to achieve the lower bound for the radio
number for the Cartesian product of the generalized Peterson graph Pm,k and a tree.
Theorem 3.3. Let Pm,k be a generalized Peterson graph of order 2m and T be a tree of order n. Denote diam(Pm,k) = dp, diam(T ) = dt and ε(T ) = ε. Then
rn(Pm,k2T ) = (2mn− 1)(dt + ε)− 4mL(T ) (8)
if there exist an ordering O(V (Pm,k2T )) := z0, z1, . . . , z2mn−1 of V (Pm,k2T ), where zt = (xit , yjt) such that the following holds for all 0 ≤ t ≤ 2mn− 2.
(a) dPm,k(xit , xit+1) = dp and for b ≥ a+ 2,
dPm,k(xia , xib) ≥
{ dp − (b− a− 1), if |W (T )| = 1;
dp − (b− a− 2), if |W (T )| = 2.
(b) LT (yj0) + LT (yj2mn−1) = 0,
(c) yjt and yjt+1 are in different branches when |W (T )| = 1 and in opposite branches when |W (T )| = 2,
and one of the following holds.
(d) min{dT (yjt , yjt+1), dT (yjt+1 , yjt+2)} ≤ (dt + 1− ε)/2 for all 0 ≤ t ≤ 2mn− 3,
(e) dT (yjt , yjt+1) ≤ (dt + 1 + ε)/2 for all 0 ≤ t ≤ 2mn− 2,
(f) For all 0 ≤ t ≤ 2mn − 1, LT (yjt) ≤ (dt + 1)/2 when |W (T )| = 1 and LT (yjt) ≤ (dt − 1)/2 when |W (T )| = 2 and for za = (xia , yja), zb = (xib , yjb) (0 ≤ a < b ≤ 2mn − 1), if yja and yjb are in the same branch of T then b− a ≥ dt + dp.
Proof. We show that if (a)-(c) and one of (d)-(f) holds for an ordering O(V (Pm,k2T )) := z0, z1, . . . , z2mn−1 of V (Pm,k2T ), where zt = (xit , yjt); 0 ≤ t ≤ 2mn− 1 then (a)-(c) of Theorem 3.2 satisfies. Since the conditions (a) and (b) are identical in both Theorems 3.2 and 3.3, we verify the condition (c) of Theorem 3.2 only. Let za = (xia , yja) and zb = (xib , yjb), 0 ≤ a < b ≤ 2mn−1 be two arbitrary vertices. Denote the right-hand side of (7) by E(a, b). We consider the following
two cases.
Case-1: |W (T )| = 1. In this case, recall that ε(T ) = 1 and δT (yjt , yjt+1) = 0 for all 0 ≤ t ≤ 2mn− 2 by the definition of δ.
Subcase-1.1: Suppose (a)-(d) holds. By (b) and (d), we have LT (yj0) = LT (yj2mn−1) = 0 < dt/2 and for all 1 ≤ t ≤ 2mn − 2, LT (yjt) ≤ min{LT (yjt−1) + LT (yjt), LT (yjt) + LT (yjt+1)} = min{dT (yjt−1 , yjt), dT (yjt , yjt+1)} ≤ dt/2. ≤ LT (yja) + LT (yjb) + 2(b− a− 1)(dt/2)− (b− a− 1)dt + (dp − b+ a+ 1) = LT (yja) + LT (yjb) + (dp − b+ a+ 1) ≤ dT (yja , yjb) + dPm,k(xia , xib).

≤ dPm,k(xia , xib) ≤ dPm,k(xia , xib) + dT (yja , yjb).

≤ LT (yja) + LT (yja+3) + 2(dt/2)− 2dt + dp − 2 = LT (yja) + LT (yja+3)− 2(dt/2) + dp − 2 ≤ LT (yja) + LT (yja+3)− 2φT (yja , yja+3) + dp − 2 ≤ dT (yja , yjb) + dPm,k(xia , xib).
If b = a+2 then either (i) dT (yja , yja+1) ≤ dt/2 and dT (yja+1 , yja+2) ≤ dt/2 or (ii) dT (yja , yja+1) ≤ dt/2 and dT (yja+1 , yja+2) > dt/2. In case of (i), LT (yja) + LT (yja+1) ≤ dt/2 and LT (yja+1) + LT (yja+2) ≤ dt/2 and hence, E(a, b) ≤ (dt/2+dt/2)−dt−2+dp+1 = dp−1 ≤ dPm,k(xia , xia+2) ≤ dPm,k(xia , xia+2) + dT (yja , yja+2). In case of (ii), LT (yja) + LT (yja+1) ≤ dt/2 and LT (yja+1) + LT (yja+2) > dt/2, that is LT (yja+1) ≤ dt/2− LT (yja). Hence,
E(a, b) = LT (yja) + 2LT (yja+1) + LT (yja+2)− dt − 2 + dp + 1
≤ LT (yja) + 2(dt/2− LT (yja)) + LT (yja+2)− dt + dp − 1 = LT (yja) + LT (yja+2)− 2LT (yja) + dp − 1 ≤ LT (yja) + LT (yja+2)− 2φT (yja , yja+2) + dp − 1
= dT (yja , yja+2) + dPm,k(xia , xii+2).
Subcase-1.2: Suppose (a)-(c) and (e) hold. Then for all 0 ≤ t ≤ 2mn−2, LT (yjt)+LT (yjt+1) ≤ (dt + 2)/2 as dT (yjt , yjt+1) ≤ (dt + 2)/2 and, yjt and yjt+1 are in different branches. If b = a+ 1 then E(a, b) = LT (yja) + LT (yjb) + dp = dT (yja , yjb) + dPm,k(xia , xib). If b = a+ 2 then
